subject: RE: [junit] Re: Unit Testing vs Integration Testing
msgSnippet: It could - assuming that their are no cracks in the integration testing. Unit testing is far easier to cover fully because each section is smaller. Integration
messageBody:
It could - assuming that their are no cracks in the integration testing. Unit testing is far easier to cover fully because each section is smaller. Integration testing involves a large number of things working together. Therefore, you know the integration testing failed - but no where it failed. When a unit test fails you have a far smaller haystack to search.

However, if I have done a proper job of unit testing against a published specification then my confidence level entering integration testing is far higher than someone that did no unit testing. Therefore, on a integration testing failure it should not be in my code.


Chip
-----
Programming: Its not just a job - its an indenture


-----Original Message-----
From: Mike Bresnahan [mailto:java-junit@...]
Sent: Friday, June 20, 2003 5:33 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Re: Unit Testing vs Integration Testing


> Unit testing gives you confidence in your objects. Integration
> testing gives you confidence in the interaction between your objects.

Doesn't integration testing give you both confidence in the interaction
between your objects and confidence in your objects?

Mike Bresnahan
